title: 113_hr4485
content: The "Fair Military Act" requires performance appraisals of Armed Forces members to include support for sexual assault prevention programs. Commanding officers' appraisals must also assess the command climate. The "Fair Military Act" mandates that commanding officers' performance appraisals evaluate their establishment of a command climate where sexual assault allegations are managed fairly and victims can report crimes without fear of retaliation. Additionally, the Act modifies military rules of evidence regarding the admissibility of general military character towards innocence probabilities. The "Fair Military Act" mandates changes to Rule 404(a) of the Military Rules of Evidence, clarifying that an accused's general military character is not admissible to show innocence probability, except when relevant to the offense. This Act also extends sexual assault prevention and response enhancements to military service academies. The "Fair Military Act" extends sexual assault prevention measures to military service academies, ensuring that the provisions of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014 apply to the academies in the same manner as they do to the Armed Forces. SEC. 6. Judicial panel assesses use of mental health records by defense in preliminary hearing and court-martial proceedings. The independent judicial panel established by the Secretary of Defense will assess the use of mental health records by the defense in preliminary hearing and court-martial proceedings, comparing it to civilian proceedings to identify any discrepancies. Results of these assessments will be included in reports required by the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2013. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report to the Committees on Armed Services of the Senate and the House of Representatives within 180 days, detailing the implementation status of sexual assault provisions in various Defense Authorization Acts and prevention initiatives announced by the Secretary of Defense.
